content.description: This is a fine steep thin crack with plenty of features.
content.protection: A single set of stoppers and small cams to 1" is probably sufficient.  Belay from the bolted rappel anchor at the top of the climb.
content.location: This is the thin steep crack just right of Calgary Stampede on the northeast face of Hidden Dome, about 75 feet left of Too Secret to Find.  A 30 meter rap from a bolted rappel station above The Screaming Poodle gets you down.

climbs.name: Too Secret to Find
climbs.fa: Pete Charkin, Alan Roberts & Bruce Howatt, 1985

content.description:
The most obvious line on this formation, this is a fun route with the crux at the top.

Climb up an easy hand crack then pull through on solid face holds to the slighly off-width trough.  Struggle through the pod as the route gets harder and harder until a nice jug presents itself just over the roof (5.10b).

Pull the overhang on big holds to easier terrain to the top.
content.protection: Pro is excellent up the entire route.  Nuts and cams in the .5" to 3" range.  Gear anchor (shared with "Balance Due") with an easy walk-off to the climber's left.

climbs.name: The Screaming Woman
climbs.fa: Dave Evans, Jim Angione, Herb Laeger, Dave Bruckman, December 1986

content.description: This fine thin crack - face climb is mentally taxing on lead.  The crux is just before the bolt with nice, easier climbing above.
content.protection: Protection thin to 2" and one bolt.  A blue alien before the bolt may hold a fall at the crux.  Bolt anchor.
content.location: This route starts at the first crack right of Tucson Bound, just left of the north prow of Hidden Dome - northeast face.  Rappel from fixed rappel anchor at the top, 30 meters.

content.description: Follow a moderate thin crack with face holds until you reach a bolt then powerful moves on very nice rock lead to the top.
content.protection: Stoppers and small cams to 2", one bolt.  Bolt anchor at top.
content.location: This is the route just left of Too Secret to Find on the northeast face of Hidden Dome.  Descend 30 meter rappel from rappel anchor at top of climb.

climbs.name: Major Creative Effort
climbs.fa: Greg Murphy and Dave Houghton, February 1987

content.description: This is a fun and varied route on excellent rock.  The first 20' is the crux - steep finger and hand jamming.  The upper half is quite easy:  5.6 or 5.7
content.location: This is an obvious crack system at the right end of the formation.  Half way up, the crack passes along the left side of a large block.  Near the top, angle right and face climb up.

content.description: Start as for balance due (crux low) but follow bolt line right on good holds toward chimney. Up the chimney for 10 or so feet on plates and edges then bust out on the upper left head wall on plates and jugs (optional pro)Â linking up with upper easy section of balance due again. Chains on top as of 1-19-20
content.location: bolt line right of balance due

climbs.name: Calgary Stampede
climbs.fa: Alan Roberts, Pete Charkin, Bruce Howatt, 1985

content.description: This route ascends an offwidth/chimney to a nice thin dihedral.  While the climbing is brief, its really pleasant, easy to protect and is a fine way to reach the summit of Hidden Rock with outstanding views.
content.protection: Gear thin nuts and cams 3", most people will want a 4" cam, gear anchor.
content.location: This route climbs the obvious thin dihedral on the far left side of Hidden Dome - Northeast Face, about 100 feet left of Too Secret to Find.  To descend from the top of Hidden Dome, easy scrambling east leads to a scary chasm jump to the ground.  Alternatively work around unpleasantly to the rap anchor above Screaming Poodle.

climbs.name: Balance Due
climbs.fa: Herb Laeger, Dave Evans & Dave Bruckman, December 1986

content.description:
This route ascends the set of short cracks to the right of "Too Secret to Find" (the main crack on this face).

Mostly face climbing with a few finger jams up to the horizontal, then delicate face moves to gain the upper crack.  The crux is the upper face section.

A fun route with interesting moves, definitely worth doing if you are in the area.

Descend from the summit of the dome by downclimbing to the climber's left back into the gully.
content.protection:
The bottom section protects surprisingly well with nuts and small TCUs.  Two bolts protect the upper face section past the horizontal crack.

A belay must be set at the top (medium cams will do).
